content.title: The View Hotel stands on the shoulders of Rabat

introduction.small: Newcomer of the Rabat skyline, The View Hotel overlooks the city and offers a magical stay, as much devoted to business as relaxation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The View Hotel stands on the shoulders of Rabat

paragraphs.text:
Whichever room you book, you are sure to enjoy unobstructed panoramic views over the Moroccan capital. This is the promise of the aptly named View Hotel. Mingling with some of the Hay Ryad business district's tallest skyscrapers, this five-star establishment bets on high-end services.
Spread over 17 floors, the 145 rooms and suites are naturally lit thanks to huge picture windows. Showcasing a contemporary style with a subtle Moroccan touch, they are fully equipped with high-tech amenities. After a full day spent working or exploring, enjoy an argan skin care or a Berber ceremonial bath at the spa. You will then gladly take a dip in the heated pool that also overlooks Rabat… a unique opportunity to swim and gaze at the sunset over the horizon line. End the day curled up in your immense bed, lost in contemplating the nighttime landscape, lulled into a dream full of stars…

The View Hotel
Avenue Annakhil
10 100 Rabat

www.theviewhotelrabat.com/en/

Rooms: from 2,138 MAD

content.title: Brunch in a secret garden at El Tropic

introduction.small: Amid Rabat's urban frenzy, this tropical-style café is always packed for brunch and tea time.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brunch in a secret garden at El Tropic

paragraphs.text:
From the threshold onwards, El Tropic's theme is apparent: dozens of plants have been laid out everywhere, matched inside with luxurious jungle-patterned wallpaper. In the back, the bright-as-gold yellow counter blends with clear wood furniture and wicker chairs. Blue and green geometrical patterns catch the eye on the tables, as you move towards the secret garden at the rear.
Under the fresco tiger's benevolent gaze, you will take a seat on one of the royal blue benches covering the stone steps, and explore the brunch's eclectic menu. There, a hrira stands alongside a Thai soup, chicken-spinach briouats, a mango lassi and eggs Benedict served with salmon. You will surely be tempted to stay in this magical place for hours, playing board games – available behind the counter – or relaxing, far from the city's frenzy.

El Tropic

content.title: Dar al-Makhzen, royal palace and seat of the government

introduction.small: Built in 1864, upon the ruins of the former royal palace, Dar al-Makhzen proudly stands in the heart of Rabat and is the seat of the government today.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar al-Makhzen, royal palace and seat of the government

paragraphs.text:
Dating back to the mid-19th century, the Royal Palace of Rabat consists of a mosque, barracks for the guard, a royal college, a small racecourse and various government buildings. While it is currently only an administrative building, its architecture remains a gem of Moroccan culture. Structures are covered with sloping green tile roofs, elegantly surrounded by gardens and large courtyards.

On the forecourt of the entrance known as the “mechouar”, celebrations in honour of the king unfold. While the private residence of Mohammed VI is established in the famous Dar es Salam district of Rabat, it hosts many receptions at Dar al-Makhzen, like the royal palaces of Meknes, Agadir, Tetouan, Fez or Tangier. For security reasons, access to the compound is restricted to authorized persons and groups accompanied by official guides. Nevertheless, the monument is well worth the detour. In addition to being the seat of the government, the Royal Palace of Rabat currently houses a Moroccan art museum, to learn more about the craft of a country full of treasures and history.

Dar el-Makhzen
Rabat

content.title: Meknes: the imperial capital of the Alawite dynasty

introduction.small: Beautiful Meknes, in northern Morocco, is a 17th-century Hispano-Moorish-style city surrounded by high walls.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Meknes: the imperial capital of the Alawite dynasty

paragraphs.text:
Only 150 kilometres separate the Moroccan capital from the historic city of Meknes, founded in the 11th century by the Almoravids, which in the 17th century became the capital of the Alawites. Located in the plain of Saïss, between the Middle Atlas and the Pre-Rif massif of Zerhoun, and so at the crossroads of trade routes, the city—a UNESCO World Heritage Site—contains the remains of the medina and the Imperial city founded by Sultan Moulay Ismail ben Cherif (1672-1727).

Behind the high walls that feature nine gates, Meknes boasts palaces, ten hammams, 25 mosques, vast granaries, vestiges of fondouks (hotels for traders), private homes, stables that can shelter 12,000 horses, and open-air water basins, all of which are proud testimonies of the Almoravid, Merinid, and Alawite dynasties. This princely planning also illustrates the specificities of the traditional adobe architecture, fashioned from a mixture of clay, sand, straw, and earth, which gives the city its special tone.

 

www.villemeknes.com

content.title: Ibn Danan Synagogue: a jewel of Moroccan Jewish culture

introduction.small: Finally renovated after two years of work, this synagogue reflects the history of a community that has been living in Fez since 1492.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ibn Danan Synagogue: a jewel of Moroccan Jewish culture

paragraphs.text:
It is written in the texts. Adopted in 2011, the new constitution enshrines the ‘Hebrew particularities' of Morocco as ‘a secular tributary' of its ‘national identity', and King Mohammed VI has called for ‘the restoration of all the Jewish temples'.

Founded in the 17th century, the oldest synagogue in Fez has been renovated after two years of work. In the first half of the 20th century, it counted 250,000 faithful, and it still caters to the largest Jewish community in North Africa. In the 1970s, it was transformed into a carpet-making workshop, then a boxing gym. Though the building was near to collapse, its wall inscriptions and its balcony were fortunately preserved; its renovation was funded by private donations, particularly from Germany. A place of worship, it is also one of Fez's special attractions.

Ibn Danan Synagogue
Fez

content.title: Fadila El Gadi: signature needlework

introduction.small: When aristocratic Rabat dresses, it does so with clothes from this designer who is the best known and most talented in Morocco.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fadila El Gadi: signature needlework

paragraphs.text:
A little girl's dream: as a child, Fadila El Gadi watched the embroiderers of Salé using golden thread. She learned this art and later enrolled in Rabat's School of Fashion before oprning her first shop. She met Yves Saint Laurent, working with him in Marrakech, and then created her own label, which is now the most exported Moroccan brand worldwide.

When we travel, we like to go shopping, be struck by a garment that everyone around us will notice, appreciate, and envy—but not own. It's human! In this slender and graceful young woman's shop, you can try on dresses, trousers, and blouses with functional, modern, and perfect cuts.

When Fadila El Gadi puts 18th-century embroidery on each piece of taffeta or silk, she infuses them with sensuality and femininity. When you wear them, regardless of your figure, you acquire what used to be called ‘distinction'. An elegant boutique to discover at any cost!

Fadila El Gadi
Avenue Allal Ben Abdallah
Rabat

www.fadilaelgadi.com

content.title: The Rue des Consuls: the shopping street

introduction.small: At the heart of the medina, this charming market alley has a name that sounds like the title of a novel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Rue des Consuls: the shopping street

paragraphs.text:
The ‘Rue des Consuls' owes its name to the ambassadors and consuls who have long lived on this street in the middle of the medina. Do you know why they set up here? When Rabat was a city of pirates, a treaty signed with the sultan allowed them to redeem Christian captives, the sale of which took place two steps away, on the Place des Oudayas.

Since then, the street has become an uninterrupted row of stalls. Unlike other souks, vendors are not insistent in Rabat. The atmosphere is friendly. Though the DVD traders are unavoidable, all that is sold here is manufactured in the workshops of the medina, including the carpets, because Rabat is the capital of the carpet. Dyed red for the most part, they are hand made, lock stitched by the Rabatians. Or let yourself be tempted by metal jewellery or a goat-leather wallet—or order a nice pair of sandals in raffia tailored especially for you.

content.title: Mohammed VI Museum: the first museum of contemporary Moroccan art

introduction.small: Although best known for its traditional skills, Morocco now has its official contemporary art museum in Rabat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mohammed VI Museum: the first museum of contemporary Moroccan art

paragraphs.text:
No, you have not mistaken the address; you are indeed before the first contemporary art museum in Morocco. Its facade often disconcerts visitors because there is nothing modern about it. This building, in the purest Moorish style, was designed to fit like a piece of a puzzle into the surrounding architecture and harmonise with the Sunnah mosque, the parliament, and the Balima. So, its interior may appear to lack character, but this is just a youthful indiscretion.

It opened its doors in 2014, so we must give it time to build its collections. Pioneers of abstract painting like Ahmed Cherkaoui, Farid Belkahia, and Jilali Gharbaoui already have their walls. Meanwhile, temporary exhibitions along with retrospectives are organised. One recently dedicated to the Mediterranean identity of the French sculptor César was a great success.

Mohammed VI Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art
Avenue Moulay El Hassan
Rabat

+212 (0) 537 769 047

www.museemohammed6.ma

content.title: The Dinarjat: discovered by lantern

introduction.small: Good Moroccan home cooking is revealed in the candlelight of this ‘riad' located in the heart of the medina.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Dinarjat: discovered by lantern

paragraphs.text:
With a glass of Meknès rosé in hand, you will never tire of the Arab-Andalusian decor of this riad, located in the heart of the medina, which is magical under candlelight. Lulled by a traditional orchestra, you will not resist its harira (traditional soup) any more than you will its kedra couscous and, for dessert, its traditional pastries like the milk and almond pastilla or its more delicate but familiar fakia, an assortment of dried fruits. In Rabat, the Dinarjat is an esteemed address of bourgeois Moroccan cuisine you will discover, following the guide, from the Boulevard el Alou, by the light of a lantern. Nothing is missing with its warm welcome and attentive service... and the memory of the melting lamb shanks with artichokes will linger for a very long time.

Restaurant Dinarjat
Boulevard el Alou
Rabat

+212 (0) 537 704 239

www.dinarjat.ma

content.title: The Oudayas Kasbah: a city within a city

introduction.small: This ‘ribat' (fortress) gave its name to the entire city. If you can only see one thing, it should be this kasbah.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Oudayas Kasbah: a city within a city

paragraphs.text:
Built in the 12th century by the Almohad, it was this ribat that housed the soldiers who went to the holy war against the Christians in Spain. The ribat became ‘Ribat El Fath', ‘Ribat the Victory' and then... Rabat. When Philip III of Spain drove out the Moors, they settled here. Therefore, when you walk about, everything reminds you of Andalusia: the whitewashed walls, the ubiquitous blue cobblestone streets, the heavy wooden doors, and the wrought iron gates.

Subsequently, this impregnable fortress became the haunt of pirates when Rabat was adopted as the headquarters of the gangsters of the sea under the name of ‘Salé-the-New'. It finally took that of ‘Oudaya' when a tribe expelled from Fez settled there in 1833. Meanwhile, the palace was built and it became the first royal residence of the Alawite rulers. Today it houses a museum of antique jewellery and remains popular for its beautiful flower garden.

In the kasbah, all is calm, almost subdued, and relaxing. Its houses are highly sought after by artists for the pleasant appeal of the quarter. Be sure to take Bazzo Street for tea or an orangeade at Café Maure whose panorama overlooks Bab Al Bahr. The view is less exotic than it once was, but it still has its charm.

Kasbah of the Udayas
Kesbat
10 030 Rabat

content.title: Kulte Gallery: the cult gallery for contemporary art

introduction.small: Much more than an exhibition space, this gallery is an incubator for new talents that then becomes their showcase.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kulte Gallery: the cult gallery for contemporary art

paragraphs.text:
In the evening, on the sidewalk of Benzerte Street, a pianist is playing John Cage and Bartók while a Tetouan artist makes stencils of yellow bats; these are clues that you are not far from the Kulte Gallery. The eleven artists exhibiting are ‘figures' of the Moroccan contemporary scene. Yasmina Naji, director of the gallery and also a founder of the Foundation for the Arts, Design, and Architecture, is an ardent supporter of her country's creative talents. This is why it is important to visit this ‘place of ideas and forms of exchange' in which you'll find emerging painters, photographers, and sculptors whose perceptions are reflected in pictures and words. The gallery organises exhibitions and happenings while doing terrific editorial work. You can take these books, which open your eyes to this other world, home in your luggage.

Kulte Gallery
Rue Benzart
Rabat

+212 (0) 537 709 237

www.artkulte.com

content.title: Vila Bea: between sea and sky

introduction.small: North of Rabat, Vila Bea is a small and idyllic hotel that you may never want to leave.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vila Bea: between sea and sky

paragraphs.text:
We bet that you will not want to leave this beach perfumed by the trade winds. How can you resist the sweets that spoil you at every meal? Why close the door to the room, whose bay windows allow only the caresses of the sun and the lapping waves?

The still-preserved village of Moulay Bousselham is a haven of peace and beauty that only a few lovers of Morocco frequent at the moment. This is where the owners of the Vila Bea have settled and built this mansion in the spirit of a house for friends and family. In its seven rooms, as on the terrace or in the dining room, it combines traditional Moroccan style with European design. The ceramics by Sidi Kacem and the walnut furniture, handmade in Marrakesh, are found alongside Pierre Paulin chairs and lamps signed by Verner Panton. Spend your days between the pool and the beach and your evenings on the terrace where you are served delicious home cooking.

Vila Bea

content.title: Skhirat: one of the most beautiful beaches in the world

introduction.small: Rabat is by the sea, but to bathe, swim, or surf, head to Skhirat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Skhirat: one of the most beautiful beaches in the world

paragraphs.text:
Skhirat, only 26 kilometres south of Rabat, boasts of being one of the most beautiful beaches in Morocco. It also receives the Blue Flag award every year, which rewards the best-kept beaches, and those that are most preserved from pollution. The royal family owns a residence and stays there regularly. You might see one or more of its members on the beach, but you will never be bothered by the security service. They know how to be discreet.

Beige sand, endless waves, deliciously salty air, and a caressing sun are what await you. And nothing else… On weekends, the Rabatians come as a family. No need to bring a picnic as you can lunch on the terrace of one of the resorts that line the beach. Or next time, rent a villa and stop in at the port to buy some freshly caught fish on your way home.

content.title: Villa Mandarine: a holiday home

introduction.small: Claudie Imbert inherited this orangery, her family home, and transformed it into a hotel that is synonymous with hospitality and absolute charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa Mandarine: a holiday home

paragraphs.text:
If you know that, in her previous life, Claudie Imbert taught art history, you might imagine with what sense of style she has transformed her home into a corner of paradise to share with you. Built around a central patio, each of its 31 rooms has a private terrace. Each also has its own decoration and is like no other. Objects, custom-made furniture, and antiques—everything here is refined.

If you opt for a room on the ground floor, you will have your own garden area and have your breakfast with the birds for company. Do not miss the delightful Baghir and Raif pancakes eaten hot with butter and honey. If you wish, you can dine at the restaurant, but also in your own private space. The entirely homemade cuisine is exquisite. In the evening, head to the pool table with a drink in hand. Do not forget to book a spa treatment and to relax in the hammam. And if you feel like a swim, the pool is heated year round.

Villa Mandarine

content.title: Marco: Rabat's great table

introduction.small: Marco's menu brilliantly shows that Moroccan cuisine knows how to reinvent itself away from its traditional dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marco: Rabat's great table

paragraphs.text:
Its location alone — on the banks of the Bouregreg River, opposite the new marina and its beautiful yachts and sailboats — reveals this restaurant's bias, which is to reinvent Moroccan cuisine. Kandil is the chef in command of this culinary journey through contemporary Morocco. He has left nothing to chance and works every taste and texture to bring a dish to an extreme degree of refinement.

Rabat is primarily a fishing port, so fish are in the spotlight, such as sole, tuna, and swordfish. The chef's specialty though is bream. Depending on the season, each one is prepared in a special way and accompanied with vegetables from an organic-market gardener in Salé. Enjoy all these dishes for lunch or dinner in a seaside atmosphere that is as chic as the dishes themselves.

Marco

Menu: around 280 MAD

content.title: The Museum of Archaeology: in pursuit of the Romans

introduction.small: The Roman Empire left its mark as far as Mogador and you can find its traces in this museum designed for all lovers of archaeology, large and small.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Museum of Archaeology: in pursuit of the Romans

paragraphs.text:
You will appreciate this museum because it has a human dimension. Opened in 1920, it is full of treasures discovered at that time, which was the golden age of archaeological excavations throughout the Mediterranean. In the main hall, the methods of prospecting, photogrammetry, restoration, and dating are explained and the main sites of Morocco are presented.

Do not miss the room devoted to prehistoric rock-art sites and the High Atlas. You will have the impression of being at the source of the Berber culture. Allow yourself time also in the Phoenician, Carthaginian, and Roman rooms. Under Juba II and Ptolemy, Rome ruled, among others, the towns of Sala, Banasa, and Volubilis. This last town is famous for its patrician villas with magnificent mosaics. You can admire some of its treasures, such as the bronze bust of Cato, as well as the statues of a young man, an old fisherman, and a dog.

Museum of Archaeology
Avenue Yacoub el Mansour
Rabat

+212 (0) 537 701 919

content.title: Sofitel Rabat Jardin des Roses: among the roses

introduction.small: In the heart of Rabat, this establishment is named for its seven-hectare Andalusian garden planted with 3,000 roses. Imagine their perfume when they all bloom…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel Rabat Jardin des Roses: among the roses

paragraphs.text:
The architects Didier Gomez and Karim Chakor designed this hotel around three elements—the rose, water, and amber—to translate the essence of pleasure and their passion for excellence. They have married French design and Moroccan craftsmanship in moucharabiehs with contemporary colours, in finely chiselled white stucco frescoes, and in carpets with zellige motifs. The Murano glass bowls and the marble chandeliers in the lobby will dazzle you.

The rooms offer absolute comfort, and dining at the restaurant Al Warda is a total delight. The chef revisits the classics of national gastronomy and raises them to the stars. This will undoubtedly inspire you to take a walk in the hotel's incredible park, which dominates the upscale Souissi quarter. Besides the heady beauty of the roses, the forest of pine and eucalyptus trees planted in the heart of the city and the ‘garden of scents' will entirely win you over. No perfumer can resist its aromatic richness.

Hotel Sofitel Rabat Jardin des Roses
Impasse Souissi

content.title: Hassan Tower: a protective figurehead

introduction.small: Facing the sea, it seems to watch over and protect the Moroccan capital. It has also become, over the centuries, the symbol of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hassan Tower: a protective figurehead

paragraphs.text:
Rabat without the Hassan Tower? It is unthinkable! You can see it from the sea and from the banks of the Bouregreg River. However, originally, the tower was a minaret—a minaret that would have been the highest in the world, calling to prayer the faithful to the biggest mosque in the world.

But fate decided otherwise. Little is known of its origins. The mosque was commissioned by Abu Yusuf Yaqub al-Mansur who wanted to make Rabat the capital of his empire, but the caliph died three years after work began in 1199. The site was abandoned, looted, and damaged. According to Spanish historians, its architecture is identical to that of the Giralda in Seville and the Koutoubia of Marrakech.

You will feel the refreshing trade winds as you stroll between the remains of the 312 marble columns of its oratory and the ruins of its walls, pierced by 14 gates. At its feet is now the mausoleum of Mohammed V, clearly demonstrating the commitment and respect that Moroccans have for this historic place.

Hassan Tower
Boulevard Mohammed Lyazidi
Rabat

+212 (0) 665 434 360

content.title: Oulja craft complex

introduction.small: If you like authentic objects that are neither kitsch nor folk, but ethno-bobo, you'll love the pottery of Salé.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oulja craft complex

paragraphs.text:
From the centre of Rabat, it takes about ten minutes by taxi to get to this place, which brings together a number of crafts workshops. Here, there are no tour buses in the parking lot, no crowds of tourists, no fake trinkets. You are happily among authentic craftsmen creating pottery and wrought iron.

Each potter exhibits and sells his or her own creations, which are very numerous. Vases, plates, dishes of all sizes, painted in sky, sand, and earth tones. It's difficult to resist these original works, so don't be surprised when you find yourself leaving with your hands full. Each piece is always well packaged and will resist the dangers of transport. You can also order custom-made pieces, but you will have to come and collect your purchases. At the rear of the shops are the workshops. You can see the craftsmen dexterously work and shape these beautiful objects. Blacksmiths create garden furniture, tables, chairs, and armchairs that will give you ideas you didn't suspect you had. Their rates are well worth the bother of arranging shipment, provided you have someone local there to follow through.

Complexe artisanal Oulia
Salé 11000

content.title: Le Grand Comptoir: a brasserie like you find in Paris

introduction.small: In a typical 1930s decor, this restaurant in the Parisian spirit features healthy, fresh market cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Grand Comptoir: a brasserie like you find in Paris

paragraphs.text:
This is an address you should definitely visit, if only to enjoy a glass of wine at the bar from vineyards around the world while nibbling tapas. The show is best taken in from there as all of Rabat comes here, seated on the mezzanine or in the dining room with its open kitchen. The menu revisits the Parisian classics with Moroccan flavours.

Everything is excellent, from the foie gras with figs to the avocado mousse with shrimp and chickpea cream, which here has acquired an exquisite lightness. The beef tartar seems right out of the belly of old Les Halles in Paris. Be tempted by the Oualidia oysters and the wild tuna steak. For dessert, all the gourmets accustomed to this address appreciate the cheesecake and crepes Suzette, which recall the friendship Rabat bears for Paris.

Le Grand Comptoir
279, Avenue Mohammed V
Rabat

+212 (0) 537 201 514

Menu: around 300 MAD

content.title: Dar Mayssane: a riad in the heart of the medina

introduction.small: How about a bath with rose petals and a four-poster bed in a room straight out of the Arabian Nights overlooking a cool courtyard bursting with flowers?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar Mayssane: a riad in the heart of the medina

paragraphs.text:
Have you ever dreamed of owning a place somewhere? It could be here in the medina. Push open the heavy carved wooden door, leave the bustle of the souks behind and enter a house of happiness. Centrally located, this traditional riad (a house with an interior courtyard) has been restored with a feminine touch. Relax with an orangeade in the flower garden. Your hosts immediately start to share the secrets of living indoors in Rabat. Sleeping Beauty, the Concubine, the Sultana, the confidante, the Lover... these are the names of the rooms.

Each is an ode to gentle rest. The white curtains protect you from the outside and create a cocoon in which you forget everything except one thing...the pleasures of the terraces where you can enjoy the view, have a glass of wine, and read a book among the bougainvillea. If desired, the cook can prepare dinner for you. In the morning, after a restorative sleep, the breakfasts are as delicious as they are plentiful.

Riad Dar Mayssane

content.title: Cosmo: under the influence of the south west

introduction.small: Chef Bernard Esquirol has transformed a beautiful Art Deco villa into a kingdom of French cuisine with a southwest accent.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cosmo: under the influence of the south west

paragraphs.text:
A beautiful Art Deco villa, an elegant room for cool evenings, and a superb terrace planted with trees and flowers facing the ramparts serve as the backdrop for French cuisine with the lilting accents of the southwest. On the menu and as a starter, it will be hard to choose between the famous gilthead bream carpaccio with herbs, the seasonal vegetables salad with parmesan chips or a mozzarella di buffala, straight from Italy, with ripe tomatoes and basil.

There is a great fish menu (salmon, monkfish) or, more simply, a grilled fillet of beef with green pepper sauce to sharpen your senses, all punctuated by a nice Moroccan wine list. The rich and varied cuisine of chef Esquirol makes the Cosmo a must in the Kingdom's capital. Finally, you cannot refuse a lemon pie under a starry night, taking in the iodic perfume of the fresh sea spray.

Restaurant Cosmopolitan
Avenue Ibn Toumert
10000 Rabat

Menu: around 300 MAD

content.title: La Table du Terminus: multiple charms

introduction.small: In the heart of Rabat, the Table du Terminus plays on the theme of a culinary brasserie that transforms in the evening into a much more lounge atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Table du Terminus: multiple charms

paragraphs.text:
From noon until 1:00 a.m., the brasserie La Table du Terminus offers a beautiful dining experience, which is followed (from 8:00 p.m.) by a much more lounge atmosphere with DJs or live music on Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays. And don't forget, of course, the inevitable happy hour from 6:00-9:00 p.m., Monday to Friday.

The chef Adil Mezzat lacks neither ambition nor creativity in the kitchen, offering homemade foie gras through to macaroons. The tournedos Rossini and mashed potatoes with truffles sing the impeccable gourmet culinary score of Gioachino Rossini, while the risotto Saint-Jacques is meltingly delicious. Add smiling and attentive service and this becomes an address that should be consumed without moderation, on two levels, with very reasonable prices right in the heart of Rabat.

La Table du Terminus
Hotel Terminus
384, Avenue Mohammed V

content.title: Villa Diyafa: in tribute to Zyriab

introduction.small: This boutique hotel is a small jewel of refinement. If you are staying elsewhere, at least go for a drink to enjoy its enchanting atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa Diyafa: in tribute to Zyriab

paragraphs.text:
Casablancans love to spend the weekend in Rabat. To relieve stress, they take refuge at Villa Diyafa. Though the hotel seems perfectly modern from the outside, its interior is nothing less than the purest Arab-Andalusian style. It pays tribute to one of the leading figures of this period, Zyriab, a musician, astronomer, and geographer who greatly influenced science, art, and even gastronomy.

The spirit of the great man lives without doubt in the library, where it is so pleasant to spend time reading, and in the work area, but also, of course, in each of the ten suites. With the large windows meeting the high ceilings, you have the impression of being in a small palace. Sounds are muted by the carpets, and in the garden you have small terraces hidden from sight for dinner with friends. As the hotel is located in the embassy district, this is where many mysterious diplomatic meetings are held.

Villa Diyafa Boutique Hotel and Spa
